name: Quillen–Lichtenbaum conjecture
rephrased: The conjecture connects étale cohomology to algebraic K-theory, specifically asserting that their ranks and orders at prime numbers match for certain algebraic structures.
implication_form: If the algebraic K-theory groups are isomorphic to étale cohomology groups, then their ranks and orders at prime numbers are equal.
explained: The Quillen–Lichtenbaum conjecture proposes a deep connection between étale cohomology and algebraic K-theory for schemes, particularly regular schemes over Dedekind domains. It predicts that the algebraic K-theory of a regular scheme X, localized at a prime p, is related to its étale cohomology via an isomorphism involving inverse limits. Specifically, for a regular scheme X proper over a strictly Henselian discrete valuation ring or a field, the Quillen–Lichtenbaum conjecture states that the pro-group completion of the algebraic K-theory of X is isomorphic to the étale cohomology of X, shifted appropriately. In simpler terms, it suggests that the higher regulators from algebraic K-theory can be understood via étale cohomology, providing a bridge between number-theoretic and topological invariants.
related_conjectures: Milnor conjecture (now proven part of Bloch-Kato)
